I.  THE TECHNICAL ASSISTANCE FACILITY 
 
A.  Justification 
 
1.  The transaction technical assistance (TA) facility will provide project preparation support 
and capacity building to a series of ensuing projects, comprising: (i) Northern Region corridor from 
Wutung to Angoram (project 1) 1, (ii) Northern Region road corridor from Lae to Malalaua (project 
2) 2; and (iii) Highlands Region Road Improvement Investment Program, Phase 2 (project 3). All 
ensuing projects are in the transport sector. To develop these projects, preparatory work in the 
form of feasibility studies, environmental and social safeguards work, financial management 
assessments, economic analysis, procurement assessment, and gender analysis will be required. 
The TA is listed in the current county operations business plan (COBP). 3  
 
2.  The Development Strategic Plan (DSP) 2010-2030 of the Government of Papua New 
Guinea (GoPNG) recognizes the northern region corridor as one of the most critical economic 
corridors  in  Papua  New  Guinea  (PNG).  The  Northern  Region  Corridor  Program  has  been 
identified as a priority investment in both the Medium-Term Development Plan III (MTDP III, 2018-
2022) and the PNG National Road Network Strategy (2018-2037). The Northern Region corridor 
starts at the Indonesian-PNG border at Wutung near Vanimo (capital of West Sepik Province), 
and extends southeast along the northern coast to Wewak (capital of East Sepik Province), 
Angoram and Madang (capital of Madang Province); then farther south via Lae (capital of Morobe 
Province) and finally to Kerema (capital of Gulf Province) on the south coast of New Guinea island. 
The total length of the Northern Region corridor is 1,457 km. It connects the ports of Vanimo, 
Wewak, Madang, and Lae to the Highlands highway and the southern region corridor.  
 
3.  The existing road along the Northern Region corridor is largely in very poor condition. 
Significant parts are unpaved earth roads, and many of them are single lanes that need to be 
widened to two lanes. The route includes three missing links: (i) Vanimo-Aitape (106 km), (ii) 
Bogia-Angoram (101 km), and (iii) Wau-Malalaua (133 km). Vanimo and Wewak ports are 
potential hubs for palm oil exports, and are in poor condition and require upgrading in terms of 
channel dredging, wharf extension and general infrastructure updates. Vanimo and Wewak have 
no customs facilities. Servicing international maritime trade from Vanimo and Wewak to Indonesia 
and beyond will play a key role in the economic growth of the northern coast area. The TA facility 
will also support the proposed second phase of the Highlands Region Investment Program which 
will improve about 400 km of the Highlands core network which is currently in poor condition. 4

C.  Cost and Financing 
 
6.  The TA facility is estimated to cost $2.5 million which will be financed on a grant basis by 
ADB’s Technical Assistance Special Fund (TASF 6). The key expenditure items are listed in 
Appendix 1.  
  
7.  The government will provide counterpart support in the form of counterpart staff, data and 
information access, facilitation of liaisons of stakeholders, and other in-kind contributions. The 
government was informed that approval of the TA does not commit ADB to finance any ensuing 
project. 
 
D.  Implementation Arrangements 
 
8.  ADB will administer the TA. The Transport and Communications Division of the Pacific 
Department will engage, supervise and evaluate consultants. The Department of Works and 
Implementation (DOWI) and the Department of Transport of the GoPNG will be the executing 
agencies.5 The  Project  Implementing  Unit  to  be  established  under  the  DOWI  will  be  the 
implementing unit. These agencies will provide necessary counterpart support, and guide the 
implementation of the TA facility to achieve the outputs within the implementation period.

E.  Governance 
 
11.  Since ADB is responsible for selecting the consultants, and disbursements in accordance 
with ADB’s Technical Assistance Disbursement Handbook (2010, as amended from time to time), 
the financial management, procurement and integrity risks during implementation of the TA facility 
are assessed to be low. Since the proposed activities consist of consulting services only, the TA 
facility is not subject for categorization as per ADB’s Safeguard Policy Statement (2009). The 
tentative gender category for the ensuing projects is effective gender mainstreaming and the TA 
facility has been categorized accordingly.  
 
II.  THE PRESIDENT'S DECISION 
 
12.  The President, acting under the authority delegated by the Board has approved the 
provision of technical assistance not exceeding $2,500,000 on a grant basis to Papua New 
Guinea for preparing the land and maritime transport projects, and hereby reports this action to 
the Board.
